config.title: Kidney disease self-assessment
config.intro_copy:
People can have kidney disease without being aware of it. There are often no symptoms until the disease is quite advanced.

Research has shown that some people are at higher risk of developing kidney disease and should have their kidney function checked even if they feel well.

Take this test to find out if 
you should have your kidney
function checked.
config.intro_copy_alt:
People can have kidney disease without being aware of it. There are often no symptoms until the disease is quite advanced.

Research has shown that some people are at higher risk of developing kidney disease and should have their kidney function checked even if they feel well.

Take this test to find out if you should have your kidney function checked.

q.title: New question
q.body: Do you have, or are you being treated for, high blood pressure?

a.body: Yes, I have high blood pressure but I'm not being treated
Yes, I am being treated for high blood pressure

q.title: New question
q.body: Have you had any of the following circulation problems? (You can pick more than one)

q.title: New question
q.body: Have you had any of the following? (You can pick more than one)

a.body: Multiple urine infections, for example three or more in a six-month period

q.title: New question
q.body: Have you been diagnosed with any of the following? (You can pick more than one)

q.title: New question
q.body: Do you have a family history of kidney disease? (You can pick more than one)

a.body: Parent or child who has a kidney disease that may be inherited
Parent or child who requires regular kidney dialysis
Parent or child who has had a kidney transplant

q.title: New question
q.body: Have you ever had a urine test that was positive for blood or protein?

q.title: New question
q.body: Are you taking any of the following drugs?(You can pick more than one)

results.ri:
Based on your responses today you are at low risk of kidney disease and don't require any further tests.

Consider the following advice to help keep your kidneys healthy in the future:

  • Avoid a diet that's high in salt and don't add salt to your food at the table
  • Drink plenty of liquids every day, about 2 litres (4 pints)
  • Stick to a healthy diet
  • Maintain a healthy weight
  • Keep active and exercise regularly
  • Don't smoke
  • Avoid regular or long-term use of pain medication, unless it has been prescribed by your doctor
  • If your symptoms do change, or you have any concerns about your health, please call NHS 111 or arrange to see your GP.

Based on your responses today if you have not had your kidney function checked before, you should make an appointment with your GP for a simple blood and urine test. Your assessment highlighted the following as possible risk factors:

Based on your responses today, if you have not had your kidney function checked before, you should make an appointment with your GP for a simple blood and urine test as soon as it can be arranged. Your assessment highlighted the following as possible risk factors:

links.li: Here are some links to articles about the kidneys and how to keep them healthy, and a video on the causes of kidney disease:

result_items.ri: Diabetes: up to 40% of people with diabetes will develop kidney disease, so regular monitoring, at least annually, is recommended.
High blood pressure: this can lead to kidney damage or, in some cases, be a sign of kidney disease
Angina: this may be associated with narrowing of the arteries that supply the kidneys, which can cause kidney damage
Heart attack: this may be associated with narrowing of the arteries that supply the kidneys, which can cause kidney damage
Stroke: this may be associated with narrowing of the arteries that supply the kidneys, which can cause kidney damage
Poor circulation: pain in the leg muscles after walking a short distance may indicate circulation problems that could be associated with kidney disease
Poor circulation: this may be associated with narrowing of the arteries that supply the kidneys, which can cause kidney damage
Aortic aneurysm: this may be associated with narrowing of the arteries that supply the kidneys, which can cause kidney damage
Heart failure: this may be associated with narrowing of the arteries that supply the kidneys, which can cause kidney damage
Multiple kidney stones: this can cause scarring of the kidneys and can result in reduced kidney function
Multiple urine infections: this can cause scarring of the kidneys, especially if they occur in children, and can result in reduced kidney function
Kidney surgery: this can cause scarring of the kidneys and can result in reduced kidney function
Enlarged prostate gland: this can cause difficulty in passing urine of having to strain during passing urine. Both can cause scarring of the kidneys and can result in reduced kidney function
Cancer of the prostate gland: this can cause scarring of the kidneys and can result in reduced kidney function
Bladder cancer: this can cause scarring of the kidneys and can result in reduced kidney function
Systemic lupus erythematosus: this can have a damaging effect on different organs in the body including your kidneys
Multiple myeloma: this can have a damaging effect on different organs in the body including your kidneys
Rheumatoid arthritis: this can have a damaging effect on different organs in the body including your kidneys
Liver disease: this can have a damaging effect on different organs in the body including your kidneys
Sickle cell disease: this can have a damaging effect on different organs in the body including your kidneys
HIV: this can have a damaging effect on different organs in the body including your kidneys
Family history: some kidney diseases are caused by abnormalities in genes that may be passed from one generation to the next
Abnormal urine test: in some, but not all, cases this can be a sign of kidney disease so it's worth further investigation
Ciclosporin: this drug may cause kidney function to decrease slowly. If you're taking it over a long period you should ask for a kidney function check at least annually
Tacrolimus: this drug may cause kidney function to decrease slowly. If you're taking it over a long period you should ask for a kidney function check at least annually
Lithium: this drug may cause kidney function to decrease slowly. If you're taking it over a long period you should ask for a kidney function check at least annually
Mesalazine: this drug may cause kidney function to decrease slowly. If you're taking it over a long period you should ask for a kidney function check at least annually

Any non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs: these drugs may cause kidney function to decrease slowly. They should not be taken over a long period, but if it's essential you should ask for a kidney function check at least annually

Help and advice on eating healthily

Go to Kidney Research UK's website

ib.title: Information on diabetes
ib.body: Diabetes is a long-term condition that affects the body's ability to process blood sugar (glucose). This is because a hormone called insulin is either absent from the body, or not working properly. It can have serious health consequences.
ib.name: Information on diabetes

ib.title: Information on high blood pressure
ib.body: High blood pressure (hypertension) is usually defined as having a sustained blood pressure of 140/90mmHg or above. If you have high blood pressure, your heart has to work harder to pump blood around your body. Over time, this can weaken it.
ib.name: Information on high blood pressure

ib.title: About circulation disease
ib.body: As well as deep vein thrombosis, circulation disease in your legs includes peripheral arterial disease. Symptoms for this include pain and/or cramping in your legs when you're walking; weakness or numbness in your legs; sores on your feet or legs; changes in the skin colour of your legs; hair loss on your feet or legs; or even pain at rest in your legs and feet.
ib.name: About circulation disease

ib.title: Information on anti-inflammatory drugs
ib.body:
The following are all non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs):

Diclofenac
Fenbufen
Fenoprofen
Ibuprofen
Indomethacin
Ketoprofen
Mefenamic acid
Nabumetone
Piroxicam
Sulindac
Tenoxicam
Tiaprofenic acid
Naproxen
ib.name: Information on anti-inflammatory drugs
